Data Types/Modalities: This code presents a deep learning approach for Alzheimer's Disease (AD) prediction using brain MRI images, exploring different transfer learning methods based on Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). The project compares pretrained 2D AlexNet with 2D-representation methods and simple neural networks with pretrained 3D autoencoders against CNNs trained from scratch, finding that pretrained 2D AlexNet achieved the best performance (86% accuracy) for classifying AD versus normal controls using structural brain changes visible in MRI scans from the ADNI dataset.
Tools/Packages: Data Modalities: - Structural MRI - Brain imaging - Gray matter - White matter

Data Types/Modalities: This code implements a web-based application for medical image recognition that specializes in analyzing 3D MRI brain images for Alzheimer's disease detection. The system uses a 3D convolutional neural network architecture to process brain MRI data and classify it into different categories (likely including Alzheimer's disease, mild cognitive impairment, and normal controls). The web interface, built with Pywebio, allows users to upload their own brain images for analysis, visualize parameter-related heatmaps, and interact with the classification results through an intuitive GUI that displays detailed diagnostic information.
Tools/Packages: Data Modalities: - Structural MRI - 3D brain imaging data - ADNI data

Data Types/Modalities: This code implements a 3D convolutional neural network (CNN) system for Alzheimer's disease diagnosis using MRI brain images. Code Summary: ## Summary This code repository contains a data science project focused on developing predictive models for Alzheimer's disease diagnosis using data from the ADNI (Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative) project. The project implements multiple machine learning approaches to classify patients into diagnostic categories (Cognitively Normal, Mild Cognitive Impairment, or Alzheimer's Disease), with the latest version using XGBoost for binary classification achieving 90.48% test accuracy. The repository includes Jupyter notebooks and R scripts that implement various classification models, evaluate their performance, and analyze feature importance, with cognitive test scores (MMSE) and age being identified as the most predictive features.

Data Types/Modalities: ADDL (Alzheimer's Disease Deep Learning) is an open-source project that applies deep learning techniques to brain MRI images for Alzheimer's disease diagnosis. The project processes structural MRI data (T1, 2017) from ADNI (Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative) database, extracting gray matter tissue images through preprocessing, then uses a ResNet deep learning module to analyze these images and implement diagnostic algorithms. The workflow achieves approximately 95% diagnostic precision by grouping ADNI MRI data into several study groups and applying different diagnostic methodologies.
Tools/Packages: Data Modalities: - Structural MRI (T1) - Brain gray matter (GM) tissue images - Neuroimaging data

Code Summary: ## Summary This code repository contains R and Python scripts for analyzing Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI) data through a two-stage process: first filtering participants based on their estimated risk for amyloid-beta positivity, then classifying them as high or low risk for future Alzheimer's Disease conversion. Code Summary: ## Summary This repository contains code for analyzing and classifying brain MRI images from the Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI) dataset using deep learning approaches. The codebase implements both a 3D convolutional neural network for classifying images into three categories (cognitively normal, mild cognitive impairment, and Alzheimer's disease) and a variational autoencoder for unsupervised learning of latent representations. Data Types/Modalities: ## Summary This project focuses on Alzheimer's disease detection and data augmentation using T1-weighted MRI brain images from the ADNI dataset. It implements a three-part approach: first creating a dataset of axial 2D slices from 3D MRI images, then training a custom ResNet-18 model to classify between healthy individuals and those with Alzheimer's, and finally developing a Wasserstein GAN (WGAN) to generate synthetic brain MRI images for data augmentation to address class imbalance issues. The WGAN approach overcomes limitations of traditional undersampling methods by avoiding data loss and replacing problematic geometric data augmentation techniques in the medical imaging context.
Tools/Packages: ## Data Modalities - T1-weighted MRI brain images - 3D volumetric neuroimaging data - 2D axial brain slices - Clinical data - Genetic data - Biological sample data

Data Types/Modalities: ### Summary This code implements a deep learning approach for Alzheimer's Disease classification using spectral-based shape features extracted from hippocampus structures in MRI scans. The repository contains code that processes triangulated surface meshes from segmented hippocampi, establishes point-to-point correspondences using spectral matching, and applies a variational autoencoder to learn low-dimensional feature representations of vertex coordinates, which are then used by a multi-layer perceptron with softmax activation for classification of subjects into normal controls, early MCI, late MCI, and Alzheimer's Disease groups.

Code Summary: ## Analysis of ADDFormer and SF2Former Code
Data Types/Modalities: The code represents two deep learning frameworks, ADDFormer and SF2Former, designed for neurological disease classification from structural MRI data. ADDFormer focuses on Alzheimer's disease detection by leveraging vision transformer architecture to capture global relationships in brain images, while SF2Former targets Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) identification using spatial and frequency domain fusion. Both frameworks employ transfer learning with ImageNet pre-trained weights, process consecutive coronal 2D slices from 3D MRI volumes, and use majority voting across slices for final subject classification. The implementations have been evaluated on public datasets (ADNI for Alzheimer's and CALSNIC for ALS) and demonstrate superior performance compared to state-of-the-art methods.
Tools/Packages: ### Data Modalities: - Structural MRI (T1-weighted) - R2* MRI - FLAIR MRI - Multi-modal neuroimaging data

Code Summary: ## Summary This code implements a deep learning-based classification system for Alzheimer's disease using MRI brain scans from the ADNI1 dataset. The approach preprocesses T1-weighted MRI images through affine transformation, skull stripping, construction of 2D images from the most informative slices based on entropy, and histogram equalization. The classification model is built on ResNet50 architecture to categorize patients into three classes: Alzheimer's disease (AD), Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI), and Normal Controls (NC). The repository includes a user interface application for clinical use, achieving 93.40% validation accuracy, 92.02% average precision, and 93.68% average recall.
Data Types/Modalities: ## Data Modalities - T1-weighted MRI - Brain imaging - Structural MRI
Tools/Packages: ## Packages, Tools, and Frameworks Used - FSL FLIRT (for affine transformation) - MNI 152 Template - ResNet50 - Adam optimizer - Python - TensorFlow/Keras (implied by neural network implementation) - Histogram equalization tools - Image processing libraries

Data Types/Modalities: This code repository presents a machine learning approach for predicting Alzheimer's disease (AD) progression trajectories and clinical subtypes. The project uses clustering techniques to identify distinct progression subgroups of AD patients and develops predictive models that can forecast disease progression four years after initial diagnosis based on the first 12 months of post-diagnosis clinical data, achieving high accuracy (AUC of 0.83-0.96 across different progression groups). The work includes an interactive web application built with Streamlit that allows clinical researchers to predict a patient's clinical subtype based on clinical parameters, with the ultimate goal of enabling more personalized treatment plans and improved clinical trial design for AD research.

Data Types/Modalities: A one-paragraph summary of the code's purpose and functionality: This repository presents a deep learning approach for multi-class Alzheimer's Disease detection and classification using brain MRI data. The project implements several convolutional neural network architectures, including VGG19, DenseNet121, and SqueezeNet, to analyze brain MRI scans from the Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI) database. The models are designed to classify subjects into different cognitive categories: normal cognition, mild cognitive impairment (MCI), and Alzheimer's Disease (AD). Data augmentation techniques such as zoom and rotation are employed to enhance model performance. Among the tested architectures, VGG19 achieved the best results with 83.2% accuracy and 96.6% AUC, followed by DenseNet121 with 79.8% accuracy and 95.7% AUC, while SqueezeNet showed the lowest performance.

Data Types/Modalities: This project focuses on predicting Mini-Mental State Exam (MMSE) scores from MRI imaging data to aid in Alzheimer's disease diagnosis, representing a modern approach to the challenge of predicting psychological states from anatomical features. The researchers used data from the Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI) to build predictive models that could potentially identify dementia before cognitive symptoms appear. They faced significant challenges including the inherent noisiness of MMSE scores, small sample size (628 patients), and high multi-collinearity in imaging data. A secondary exploration attempted to predict beta-amyloid plaque presence from blood sample gene expression profiles, which could potentially replace more invasive diagnostic procedures like CSF sampling and PET scans.

Code Summary: ## Summary This code implements a comprehensive framework for classifying Alzheimer's disease stages (Cognitively Normal, Mild Cognitive Impairment, and Alzheimer's Disease) using multiple deep learning approaches on MRI brain scans from the ADNI dataset. The project employs three distinct neural network architectures: a dual 2D CNN model with feature fusion, a 3D ResNet-18 model for volumetric analysis, and a transfer learning approach using VGG16 pre-trained weights. The pipeline includes extensive preprocessing steps such as DICOM to NIfTI conversion, bias field correction, registration, skull stripping, and normalization, with the best-performing models achieving validation accuracies of 85-90% and AUC values of 0.92-0.98 across different disease classifications.

Data Types/Modalities: This code repository contains a project focused on improving Alzheimer's disease (AD) diagnosis and predicting Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) to AD conversion by comparing four post-hoc harmonisation techniques (ComBat, CovBat, ComBat-GAM, and NeuroHarmony) on neuroimaging data from the Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI) dataset. The project builds two classifiers using cortical thickness data from a cohort of 1358 participants to evaluate how different harmonisation methods affect classification performance, with statistical significance assessed using the McNemar test to determine which techniques most effectively reduce variability introduced by differences in imaging protocols and scanning devices.
Tools/Packages: Data Modalities: - Structural MRI - Cortical thickness measurements - Demographic data - Genetic data

Code Summary: A one-paragraph summary of the code's purpose and functionality: This repository contains a project focused on testing whether DNA methylation can serve as a biomarker for predicting Alzheimer's disease and detecting pre-symptomatic cognitive impairment. The work involves analyzing case-control datasets (GSE156984, GSE153712, and ADNI) to identify significant CpG site biomarkers based on p-values, then using these biomarkers with machine learning algorithms to create both static and progressive prediction models. The static model achieved 80.3% accuracy in distinguishing mild cognitive impairment (MCI) patients from controls, while the progressive models demonstrated 86.1% accuracy in predicting normal-to-MCI conversion and 90.9% accuracy in predicting MCI-to-Alzheimer's conversion over a two-year period, supporting the hypothesis that DNA methylation can effectively predict Alzheimer's disease progression.
Data Types/Modalities: Data types and data modalities mentioned or used: - DNA methylation data - CpG site biomarkers - Case-control datasets - Cognitive assessment data
Tools/Packages: Packages, tools, and frameworks used: - Machine learning algorithms - Support Vector Classification (SVC) - Lasso algorithm - Data analysis programs

Data Types/Modalities: A one-paragraph summary of the code's purpose and functionality: This repository contains code for analyzing the contribution of genetic factors in predicting Alzheimer's disease status at baseline using data from the University of Southern California Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI) database. The researchers worked with two datasets: ADNIMERGE_full and ADNI_Gene_Expression_Profile, focusing specifically on the ADNI2 cohort due to gene expression data availability. They built predictive models using regularized logistic cross-validation as a baseline (78.6% accuracy), then improved performance by incorporating gene expression data through PCA combined with logistic regression (83% accuracy) and Random Forest (82.14% accuracy at depth 3), demonstrating that genetic factors can enhance prediction accuracy for Alzheimer's status.

Data Types/Modalities: This repository contains research on Alzheimer's Disease (AD) progression using diffusion-weighted imaging data from a longitudinal study of 264 subjects. The code analyzes brain-wide structural connectomics in early AD stages, focusing on the predictive potential of diffusion data. The researchers discovered a potential prognostic biomarker based on hemispheric lateralization of mean tract volume for tracts originating from supramarginal and paracentral regions, which achieved 86% accuracy, 86% sensitivity, and 93% specificity when combined with clinical indicators. While diffusion-weighted imaging measurements alone weren't strongly predictive, the comprehensive tract-by-tract analysis illuminates the potential of diffusion MRI for early detection and monitoring of neurodegenerative diseases, emphasizing the importance of multi-modal data integration for enhanced predictive analytics.
Tools/Packages: Data Modalities: - Diffusion-weighted MRI - Structural connectomics - Clinical variables

The dataset consists of information from 220 subjects, including various brain region measurements such as whole brain volume, estimated intracranial volume, ventricles, hippocampus (left and right), inferior lateral ventricles, temporal lobe regions, fusiform, and entorhinal cortex measurements, which are used as features for the classification task.
Tools/Packages: Data Modalities: - Structural MRI - Brain morphometry - Volumetric measurements - Neuroanatomical features - Clinical diagnosis

Code Summary: ### Summary This code implements a graph neural network (GNN) approach to predict Alzheimer's disease diagnosis using protein expression data from the Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI). The project constructs protein co-expression networks where proteins are represented as nodes with expression levels as node features, and correlations between proteins form the edges. The methodology employs hierarchical clustering with Graph Convolutional Networks (GCN) to generate embeddings reflecting local graph structures, followed by ASAPool clustering to make graph-level predictions of disease status based on individuals' proteomic profiles from cerebrospinal fluid samples.
Data Types/Modalities: ### Data Modalities - Proteomics (cerebrospinal fluid protein expression data) - Clinical data (disease diagnosis) - Biomarkers (CSF biomarkers)
Tools/Packages: ### Packages, Tools, and Frameworks Used - Graph Neural Networks (GNN) - Graph Convolutional Networks (GCN) - ASAPool (Adaptive Structure Aware Pooling) - Hierarchical clustering - Biweight mid-correlation (for adjacency matrix construction)

Data Types/Modalities: ## Summary of Code's Purpose and Functionality This project employs advanced Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) with 3D ResNet architecture enhanced by Convolutional Block Attention Module (CBAM) for automated segmentation and analysis of MRI brain images to detect Alzheimer's Disease. The approach includes comprehensive data preprocessing, MRI registration, and data augmentation techniques using datasets from ADNI and OASIS. The system classifies subjects into three categories: Alzheimer's Disease (AD), Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI), and Cognitively Normal (CN), achieving high accuracy rates across various experimental configurations, particularly when focusing on six specific regions of interest (ROIs) in the brain.
Tools/Packages: ## Data Modalities - 3D MRI brain images (T1-weighted) - Neuroimaging Informatics Technology Initiative (NIfTI) images - Patient demographic and clinical information (CSV files)

Data Types/Modalities: This code repository contains the implementation for analyzing the stage-dependent differential influence of metabolic and structural networks on memory across the Alzheimer's disease continuum. The main program is in vc.R, with run_vc.R providing an example implementation used in the referenced paper. The code utilizes a Sparse Structured Shrinkage Estimator for Nonparametric Varying-Coefficient Models, which requires pre-compiled Fortran 90 code. This computational approach allows researchers to examine how different brain networks (metabolic and structural) influence memory function at various stages of Alzheimer's disease progression.
Tools/Packages: Data Modalities: - Brain structural connectivity - Brain metabolic networks - Memory performance data - Alzheimer's disease staging data

Code Summary: ## Summary This project aims to create a tool for early detection of Alzheimer's disease using brain MRI images extracted from the ADNI database, leveraging a Kaggle dataset. The approach implements the Crow-search algorithm, a nature-inspired machine learning method based on work by S. Labaadi et al. (2019), to classify different stages of Alzheimer's disease development. The project builds upon existing repositories and requires a specific four-class Alzheimer's dataset from Kaggle for reproduction of results.

Data Types/Modalities: **Summary:** This project aims to develop an early detection and analysis system for Alzheimer's disease using brain MRI images from the ADNI (Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative) database and MMSE (Mini-Mental State Examination) test data. The codebase contains multiple analysis components including image segmentation through thresholding of brain MRIs, multiple regression analysis using MMSE scores, longitudinal MRI analysis for predictions using OASIS data, edge detection techniques for enhanced brain MRI analysis, and a KNN classification algorithm for Alzheimer's disease analysis.

Code Summary: ## Summary This code implements a deep learning model for Alzheimer's disease classification using brain MRI scans. It utilizes GFNet (Global Filter Networks), a specialized vision transformer architecture designed for medical imaging tasks, which replaces traditional self-attention mechanisms with Fourier transform operations for improved efficiency. The model was trained on the Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI) dataset, achieving 90% accuracy on validation data and 76.57% on the test set, demonstrating its ability to distinguish between Alzheimer's Disease (AD) and Normal Control (NC) cases.

Code Summary: ## Summary This code repository contains a machine learning project focused on detecting Alzheimer's disease through brain MRI analysis. The project uses a 3D DenseNet model to classify brain MRIs into two diagnostic categories: Cognitively Normal (CN) and Alzheimer's Disease (AD). Using the ADNI dataset from the University of South Carolina, the project processes 2073 T1-weighted brain MRIs, achieving a final F1-Score of 84.39%, Precision of 82.63%, Recall of 86.23%, AUC of 88.60%, and Accuracy of 89.39% on the test set after preprocessing the images and training the model.

Data Types/Modalities: This code repository presents a deep neural network approach for imputing missing data in heterogeneous Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI) datasets and subsequently performing classification. The project implements a denoising autoencoder (DAE) for handling missing data at varying levels (40%-70%) in specific columns (MOTHDEM, APoE, CDR), followed by Random Forest classification for Alzheimer's disease severity prediction. The workflow includes data preprocessing, feature selection using multiple methods (Boruta, logistic regression with L1 regularization, and autoencoder), missing data generation and imputation, and model evaluation using standard metrics like accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 score.
Tools/Packages: Data Modalities: - Neuropsychological assessments (MOTHDEM, CDR) - Genetic data (APoE) - Demographic data (gender) - Heterogeneous biomedical data

Data Types/Modalities: A one-paragraph summary of the code's purpose and functionality: This repository presents a deep learning approach for automated classification of Alzheimer's Disease (AD), Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI), and elderly controls (CN) using structural MRI scans. The project utilizes Convolutional Neural Networks to analyze hippocampal gray matter, which is known to correlate strongly with Alzheimer's Disease. The workflow includes skull stripping, segmentation, normalization, and standardization of 3D sMRI data from the ADNI database (864 patients), followed by a 2D+ approach that selects representative slices from each dimension to avoid computationally intensive volumetric processing. The model architecture consists of convolutional layers, ReLU activations, max pooling, and linear layers, with weighted cross-entropy loss to handle class imbalance. The classifier achieved 100% accuracy in distinguishing AD from CN, and 75.4% accuracy in the three-class classification (AD, CN, MCI), with perfect detection of AD cases.
Tools/Packages: Data types and data modalities mentioned or used: - Structural MRI (sMRI) - Hippocampal gray matter segmentations - 3D brain imaging data - 2D brain image slices

Data Types/Modalities: A one-paragraph summary of the code's purpose and functionality: This repository contains code and resources for analyzing multi-modal MRI and resting-state functional MRI (rsfMRI) data from the Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI) cohorts. It includes shell scripts and R code used to process and analyze neuroimaging data to study the progression of Alzheimer's disease across different stages, from cognitively normal (CN) to mild cognitive impairment (MCI) to Alzheimer's disease (AD). The repository documents two major studies: a 2019 cross-sectional study using ADNI2 data that demonstrated changes in rsfMRI preceding structural MRI changes during disease progression, and a 2022 study using ADNI3 data that examined progression from CN to subjective memory complaints (SMC) to early and late MCI. The workflow incorporates various neuroimaging processing tools and statistical analysis methods to extract meaningful patterns from brain imaging data.
Tools/Packages: Data types and data modalities mentioned or used: - Structural MRI - Resting-state functional MRI (rsfMRI) - Multi-modal MRI - Neuroimaging data - High-dimensional time series

Code Summary: ``` This code represents an HTML webpage describing a deep learning-based system for early Alzheimer's disease detection using MRI scans. The system employs a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) based on the ResNet50 architecture pre-trained on ImageNet, which is fine-tuned to identify structural brain changes associated with different stages of Alzheimer's disease (Non-Demented, Very Mild Demented, Mild Demented, and Moderate Demented). The model initially achieved 35.03% test accuracy after 2 epochs, but improved to 90-95% accuracy with additional training, and includes features like Grad-CAM for visual explanations, automated report generation, data augmentation, and real-time inference capabilities. ```
Data Types/Modalities: Data types and data modalities: - MRI scans - Structural brain imaging - Neuroimaging
Tools/Packages: Packages, tools, and frameworks used: - ResNet50 - Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) - Transfer learning - Grad-CAM - ImageNet (pre-training dataset)

Data Types/Modalities: A one-paragraph summary of the code's purpose and functionality: This code implements a 3D Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) system for Alzheimer's disease diagnosis based on MRI brain images. The system provides a web application interface that allows users to upload brain MRI images for analysis, processes them through a trained PyTorch model, and returns a classification result. The architecture includes a 3D CNN model (ClassificationModel3D) with four convolutional layers, batch normalization, max pooling, and fully connected layers that ultimately outputs a classification into one of five categories. The system is designed to be user-friendly with a web interface for image upload and result visualization, making advanced medical image analysis accessible through a simple application.
Tools/Packages: Data types and data modalities mentioned or used: - MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) - 3D brain images - Neuroimaging data

Code Summary: ## Summary This project develops a machine learning model to predict Alzheimer's disease stages using features extracted from MRI imaging and demographic data. The code implements a convolutional neural network (CNN) with three convolutional layers, max pooling, and dense layers to classify brain MRI scans into five different phases of Alzheimer's disease. The workflow includes data exploration, image preprocessing (resizing to 128x128 pixels, grayscale conversion, normalization), model development with TensorFlow/Keras, hyperparameter optimization using Keras Tuner, and evaluation through 5-fold cross-validation.

Code Summary: A one-paragraph summary of the code's purpose and functionality: This code repository contains scripts for analyzing white matter structure in Alzheimer's disease using data from the Department of Defense Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (DoD-ADNI). The repository includes tools for both microstructure and macrostructure analyses of white matter. For microstructure analyses, the code utilizes FreeSurfer's TRACULA for along-tract statistics and visualization, with scripts for statistical analysis (tracula_stats.sh), data concatenation (concatenate_tracula_profile_data_max.py), and tract profile visualization (tract_profile_plot.py). For white matter macrostructure analyses, the repository includes R scripts implementing robust regression using the MASS package. Additionally, the code supports cognitive performance analyses through elastic net regressions implemented in R using the glmnet package, allowing researchers to examine relationships between white matter integrity and cognitive function in Alzheimer's disease.
Data Types/Modalities: Data types and data modalities mentioned or used: - Diffusion MRI - White matter microstructure - White matter macrostructure - Cognitive assessment data
Tools/Packages: List of packages, tools, and frameworks used: - FreeSurfer's TRACULA - mri_glmfit - Python (for data concatenation and visualization) - R - MASS package (for robust regression) - glmnet package (for elastic net regression)

Data Types/Modalities: A one-paragraph summary of the code's purpose and functionality: This project implements a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) for classifying and predicting different stages of Alzheimer's disease using MRI data from the Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI) dataset. The code processes MRI images by resizing them to 100x100 pixels and converting them to grayscale, then applies a CNN architecture with multiple convolutional layers, batch normalization, and dropout to classify subjects into five categories: Cognitively Normal (CN), Early Mild Cognitive Impairment (EMCI), Late Mild Cognitive Impairment (LMCI), Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI), and Alzheimer's Disease (AD). The model achieves an overall accuracy of 97.86% with F1-scores ranging from 0.98 to 1.00, demonstrating effective performance for early detection and diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease.
Tools/Packages: Data types and data modalities mentioned or used: - MRI (structural neuroimaging) - Brain imaging data - Neuroimaging data

Data Types/Modalities: ## Summary This project develops a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) binary classifier to differentiate between Alzheimer's Disease (AD) and Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) using neuroimaging data from the Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI). The code includes preprocessing of DICOM format medical images, converting them to matrices and PNG format for analysis, and implementing a CNN model to distinguish between these two conditions, which is critical for appropriate treatment strategies as MCI represents a transitional stage between age-related memory decline and more severe dementia.
Tools/Packages: ## Data Modalities - Neuroimaging (MRI) - DICOM medical images - Brain scans

Code Summary: ## Summary This code repository contains analysis tools for predicting conversion from Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) to Alzheimer's Disease (AD) using machine learning approaches. The main focus is on a Random Forest classification model that leverages functional activity questionnaire data from informants, cognitive test scores, and brain volume measurements from MRI to identify early predictors of AD conversion. The code implements various model interpretability techniques including Gini importance, permutation importance, SHAP values, and partial dependency plots to demonstrate that even subtle changes in daily functioning reported by informants can significantly predict future AD conversion, alongside traditional biomarkers like hippocampal volume and memory test performance.
Data Types/Modalities: ## Data Modalities - Clinical assessments (Functional Activity Questionnaire, Geriatric Depression Scale) - Neuropsychological tests (verbal memory, executive function) - Structural MRI (hippocampal volume, lateral ventricle volumes) - Longitudinal clinical data

The content suggests this repository may be part of a research project investigating how these regulators' dysregulation could contribute to neurodegenerative processes in AD.

Code Summary: ## Summary Aliro is an easy-to-use data science assistant designed for researchers without machine learning or coding expertise, providing a clean web interface for supervised machine learning analysis. It offers results visualization and reproducible scripts, and features an AI assistant that recommends appropriate analyses based on a knowledge base that grows as more experiments are run. The system comes pre-loaded with knowledge from the PMLB benchmark suite and is actively developed by the Center for AI Research and Education (CAIRE) in the Department of Computational Biomedicine at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center.

Code Summary: ## Summary TPOT (Tree-based Pipeline Optimization Tool) is a Python Automated Machine Learning tool that optimizes machine learning pipelines using genetic programming. It serves as a Data Science Assistant by automatically searching for the optimal combination of preprocessing, feature selection, and modeling techniques to maximize performance for a given dataset. The tool recently underwent a major refactoring to improve efficiency, support new features like genetic feature selection, multi-objective optimization, and provide a more modular framework for customizing the evolutionary algorithm.

Code Summary: A one-paragraph summary of the code's purpose and functionality: AlzKB is a knowledge base for AI research in Alzheimer's Disease, built on graph database technology. It integrates data from various third-party sources into a unified knowledge graph that can be queried and analyzed. The repository provides tools to either download a pre-built database dump in CYPHERL format for import into Memgraph (replacing the deprecated Neo4j in versions 1.3.0+) or build the knowledge graph from scratch by fetching original data sources, populating an OWL ontology, and loading the contents into a graph database. AlzKB serves as a comprehensive resource for researchers studying Alzheimer's Disease, allowing them to explore relationships between various biomedical entities through graph-based queries.
Data Types/Modalities: Data types and data modalities mentioned or used: - Knowledge graphs - Ontologies (OWL 2) - Graph databases
Tools/Packages: List of packages, tools, and frameworks used: - Memgraph Lab/Server - Python (3.7+) - MySQL - ista (external library for OWL ontology population) - Neo4j (deprecated in versions prior to v1.3.0) - CYPHERL (file format for graph database import/export)

Data Types/Modalities: This code implements an unsupervised deep learning approach for deriving imaging-based endophenotypes (UDIPs) from brain MRI data to enable genetic association studies. The repository contains a 3D convolutional autoencoder architecture that compresses brain imaging data into a 128-dimensional latent space, which is then used to identify genetic variants associated with brain structure. The framework includes a perturbation-based decoder-interpretation (PerDI) method to map specific genetic loci to brain regions without human labels, successfully identifying genes relevant to brain structures like the Thalamus, Pallidum, and Putamen, with the overall approach identifying 9,457 significant SNPs organized into 97 independent genetic loci.
Tools/Packages: Data Modalities: - Structural MRI (T1 and T2) - Genetic data (SNPs) - Brain imaging-derived phenotypes - Neuroimaging endophenotypes

Data Types/Modalities: A one-paragraph summary of the code's purpose and functionality: This repository contains scripts for downloading and processing exome sequencing data from the Alzheimer's Disease Sequencing Project (ADSP). The code facilitates the connection to ADSP buckets, downloads exome slices, and processes the data for t-test analysis to compare "physchem" (likely physical-chemical properties). The workflow includes setting up prerequisites (samtools, go, fuse-utils, goofys), mounting ADSP buckets to local storage, downloading reference hg38 files from the Broad Institute, and handling potential library issues. The main download functionality is implemented in ADdownload.sh which depends on urlget.py.
Tools/Packages: Data types and data modalities mentioned or used: - Genomic sequencing data (exome sequencing) - BAM files - Reference genome (hg38)

Code Summary: ## Summary This repository contains code for identifying healthy individuals with Alzheimer's disease neuroimaging phenotypes in the UK Biobank, as presented in a Communications Medicine paper. The codebase implements a machine learning model that analyzes neuroimaging data to detect AD-like phenotypes in cognitively normal individuals. The repository includes scripts for training and inference, data preprocessing pipelines, and Bayesian statistical analysis tools, with the model architecture defined in Python using PyTorch and tracked using Weights & Biases for experiment organization and reproducibility.
Data Types/Modalities: ## Data Modalities - Structural MRI - Neuroimaging phenotypes - Clinical scores - Demographic data - UK Biobank data - ADNI (Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative) data - NACC (National Alzheimer's Coordinating Center) data

Data Types/Modalities: This code presents a project focused on developing a deep learning model to predict different progressive levels of Alzheimer's Disease (AD) using data from the National Alzheimer's Coordinating Center (NACC). The project implements a sequential neural network model in TensorFlow to classify patients into four categories: no impairment (0.0), questionable impairment (0.25), mild impairment (0.5), and moderate & severe impairment (1.0). The analysis addresses challenges of an unbalanced dataset, with most patients falling into the no impairment category, and explores relationships between age and disease progression. The model architecture uses multiple hidden layers with ReLU activation, dropout for regularization, and a softmax output layer, achieving 85.62% accuracy but showing bias toward the dominant class, suggesting the need for oversampling methods to improve performance on minority classes.
Tools/Packages: Data Modalities: - Clinical assessments (MOCA scores) - Demographic data (age) - Functional status measures - Cognitive assessment scores - Residential status information

Data Types/Modalities: This code focuses on detecting cell walls and protein hotspots in fluorescence images of yeast cell models used to study neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and Huntington's. The project utilizes OpenCV for image processing to analyze fluorescence microscopy images, specifically identifying protein aggregations that are characteristic of these diseases. By post-processing fluorescence images, the code aims to map the hyperlocalization of biological processes and biomaterial transport at the cellular level, providing insights into the erratic misfolding of proteins that leads to functional degeneration of cells in neurodegenerative conditions.
Tools/Packages: Data Modalities: - Fluorescence microscopy images - Cellular imaging data - Protein aggregation data - Yeast cell model data

Data Types/Modalities: A one-paragraph summary of the code's purpose and functionality: This repository contains a deep learning model for classifying Alzheimer's disease using MRI brain images. The project implements a custom convolutional neural network that outperformed other approaches in detecting patterns indicative of Alzheimer's disease from brain MRI scans. The model classifies brain images into different stages of dementia, though it faced challenges with limited data for the "Moderate Demented" class. The implementation includes early stopping techniques to prevent overfitting and ensure better generalization to unseen data. While achieving satisfactory results, the authors note that further optimization, additional data collection, and hyperparameter tuning would be required before clinical deployment.
Tools/Packages: Data types and data modalities mentioned or used: - MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) - Brain imaging - Structural neuroimaging

Data Types/Modalities: DxSter is an Alzheimer's Algorithmic Diagnostic Helper module that takes a Clinical diagnosis (PhyDx) and Neuropsychological diagnosis (NpDx) to output an algorithmic diagnosis (AlgDx), with the goal of saving time in formulating Alzheimer's disease diagnoses by reducing the need for consensus conferences. The module implements a diagnostic algorithm based on established research that can be used programmatically in Python or JavaScript, with example implementations provided for both languages, including a web-based calculator and command-line processing of CSV data files.
Tools/Packages: Data Modalities: - Clinical diagnosis data - Neuropsychological assessment data - CDR (Clinical Dementia Rating) scores
